title: Before 1 January 2020, will General Motors launch a ride-hailing service open to the public in the U.S. which uses autonomous vehicles?
possible_answers: Yes, using only vehicles with steering wheels
Yes, using only vehicles without steering wheels
Yes, using at least some vehicles without steering wheels
preds: There are still a number of testing and verification required for this sort of service to be deemed safe.

As of 2019, Cruise is focusing on testing their vehicles in select cities. The company is testing its vehicles in various cities across California, Arizona, and Michigan. According to Ammann, “In order to reach the level of performance and safety validation required to deploy a fully driverless service in San Francisco, we will be significantly increasing our testing and validation miles over the balance of this year, which has the effect of carrying the timing of fully driverless deployment beyond the end of the year.” In addition, GM asked the federal government for clearance on developing self-driving cars that lack parts like steering wheels. The US Department of Transportation won’t make a decision on the request until at least 2020.
https://emerj.com/ai-adoption-timelines/self-driving-car-timeline-themselves-top-11-automakers/

Back up from 17% for ‘yes’. A spokesperson said the 2019 deadline is still in place: http://gmauthority.com/blog/2019/06/gm-ceo-mary-barra-sidesteps-cruise-self-driving-taxis-timeline/ On the other hand, GM’s CEO has been quiet about the plans. This suggests they may not be on track. Yet, this notion that “just because they are quiet about it means that the target is not a high priority or they are not on track” is based on viewing the issue from the perspective of a public and vocal CEO. But one must also consider that there are different leadership styles. Not all CEOs will publicly hype an upcoming and uncertain product. Not all CEOs will easily accept the risk of overpromising. So I am assigning a significant probability of 25% due to two main factors:
* launching something by the end of the year remains a target for the company (see above)
* the threshold for this question is low enough that this “something” will qualify. As I’ve written in previous comments, a limited geographical coverage, with pre-screening of customers, and a safety driver all do not disqualify a service from meeting the standard of this question.

"“We will be gated by safety, we’re working aggressively,” Barra said in her address. “We have also worked very specifically on what safety demonstration we have to make … as we achieve those milestones we will then be in a position – in a geo-fenced environment – to be able to truly launch an AV system in a rideshare environment without a driver.” 
Source: https://www.detroitnews.com/story/business/autos/general-motors/2019/06/04/gm-ceo-barra-avoids-driverless-taxi-timeline-cruise-update/1337371001/ If true, that form of self-driving taxi rollout by GM Cruise may not 'count' for this question.

GE has confirmed that steering wheels are "most likely":  General Motors' initial fleet of autonomous vehicles for public use will "most likely" include manual controls such as steering wheels and pedals, according to the company's head of electric and autonomous vehicles." [1] I am reducing likelihood of 'yes' on account of how coy GE has been about meeting the target this year:  "Ammann and other executives, including GM CEO Mary Barra and President Mark Reuss, have consistently said the launch of the self-driving, ride-hailing fleet for public use would be "gated by safety" — a term Parks reiterated when asked about plans to launch the fleet this year." [1] https://www.autonews.com/mobility-report/gms-initial-avs-likely-be-equipped-manual-controls-key-exec-says

Been cautious on this one, but I think the rash of problems suggests its not going to be ready in this time frame. "Doug Parks, GM’s vice president of autonomous and electric vehicle programs, told Automotive News this week that it will no longer ahead with the plan to roll out a self-driving car that lacks standard controls."[1] "What is clear from the documents is that Cruise misjudged how quickly its software would reach the final milestone, known as Apollo. Engineers led by then-CEO Kyle Vogt believed that partly by hiring more people Cruise would be able to improve its software exponentially. Instead, Cruise and other major programs in the industry improved quickly at first, but then saw diminishing returns from software development. As a result, Cruise lowered the bar on some of the secondary milestones it would need to achieve before reaching Apollo. Still, Cruise has made progress, completing two of the four primary safety-related milestones it set for itself two years ago, related to the frequency with which it encounters incidents that likely would have resulted in a collision if not for a human backup driver taking control."[2] [1] https://www.autonews.com/mobility-report/gms-initial-avs-likely-be-equipped-manual-controls-key-exec-says
[2] https://www.theinformation.com/articles/cruises-secret-apollo-robotaxi-milestones

Reports that GM plans to double head count for Cruise in the coming months: https://www.fool.com/investing/2019/03/13/gm-doubles-down-self-driving-with-a-planned-hiring.aspx
I am not saying that doubling head count will double the probability as might be inferred when comparing my previous forecast with this one, but I now think my previous forecast was a bit too pessimistic to start with. It surely will take 2-3 months to hire that many staff and get them to full productivity. That leaves ~6 months to roll out the service, which is not impossible but ambitious. It's also hard to judge how far along they are right now and whether the hiring spree is an indication that they know how to push it over the finish line, or whether it is an act to compensate for lagging behind schedule.
Given the regulatory hurdles they still face, and the lack of apparent progress resolving them, I am shifting a bit toward no.

As the technology industry continues research and development in field of autonomous machines, the hope for autonomous vehicles is growing and becoming closer to application. GM CEO Mary Barra is directing  the company into a path to which she believes the future will focus on, which is self-driving cars in the drive-hailing service. However, as this gets closer to becoming a reality, the issues it brings are becoming more obvious. There are policies and laws that have yet to be addressed when it comes to autonomous vehicles on the road. These cars may have difficulty accounting for certain laws of the road and for humans' improv on the road. Should a crash occur, the question of fault who come into play as one wouldn't know who to attribute the mistake too. With this, then you would have to look at whether it was the hardware or software of the autonomous car. GM must also listen to its audience; many of whom show large amounts of apprehension in placing themselves or loved ones in a car without a driver. Because of these reasons, the likelihood of GM launching an autonomous vehicle hauling service is unlikely in the time span of less than a year.  https://www.sfchronicle.com/business/article/Car-industry-in-a-nutshell-GM-shrinks-while-13422522.php
https://www.law.com/legaltechnews/2019/03/26/gm-request-for-fully-autonomous-cars-faces-legal-speed-bumps/?slreturn=20190226150806

https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-03-14/americans-still-fear-self-driving-cars

As of 2018, Cruise has accomplished roughly the disengagement frequency (0.19 disengagements per 1000 miles) that Waymo had in 2017 (0.18) before it launched its ride hailing service in 2018.  I am only increasing the odds slightly (from 20%) because these statistics are not necessarily comparable across companies. Each report is generated by the respective company, and they used different explanations for what caused the disengagement so there are different categories of events being counted.  Nevertheless, Cruise is making significant progress compared to where it was last year, and the criteria for this question to count as a "yes" are not prohibitively strict. [1] https://www.dmv.ca.gov/portal/wcm/connect/aaedb53c-a3c4-44bf-937e-741884d2792a/GMCruise.pdf?MOD=AJPERES&CVID=

Affirming. Looks like GM's petition for steering wheel free cars hasn't advanced: "It has been more than a year since GM petitioned NHTSA, the nation's top safety regulator, for permission to deploy self-driving vehicles that don't have manual controls such as steering wheels and pedals to operate on U.S. roadways, and get around 16 requirements under Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standards that cover vehicles with human drivers. Barra said Wednesday that there was no update on that petition, which the company was hoping to have approved for its plans to launch an autonomous ride-hailing fleet in 2019. She said the company is "in good position" and capable of launching the service with its third-generation vehicles, which have manual controls." [1] [1] https://www.autonews.com/mobility-report/gms-spending-autonomous-vehicles-comes-below-forecast

Following @Emil, thanks to his data and analysis at https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/821320

As I wrote earlier [1], the recent clarification is helpful because now we know that Waymo's service fulfills the question criteria, raising the question: "How far behind is GM?" A good metric to go by is disengagements per thousand miles (DPTM). Miles driven may also be important but it can mislead because some companies (Way, Uber) racked a lot of miles in Phoenix, which is an easier test bed than San Francisco [2]. This means that their cars were learning less than Cruise's cars, which are encountering all sorts of more challenging situations in San Francisco.   In terms of DPTM, Cruise is where Waymo was in 2015 (0.8) [3] This suggests that they have a lot of catching up to do. Though, it's worth pointing out that it took Waymo one year to lower that number to 0.2, where it essentially flatlined (in 2017, Waymo was at 0.18, no data for 2018 yet that I've seen) [3]. Admittedly, Waymo drove ~600k miles in 2016 (whereas Cruise drove just over 100k in 2017 so it's hard to see them driving 600k miles in 2018, but again, miles driven has its flaws as an indicator).  Counterargument - but isn't AV tech really far away from prime time? Sure, in a sense, but it's worth pointing out that Cruise's 0.8 number is two orders of magnitude better than most AV companies [3] with the exception of Nissan and Zoox (compared to those, Cruise is one order of magnitude better). So when folks talk about the challenges of AV technology we should keep in mind that Cruise is far ahead of the competition (with the exception of Waymo of course).  Conclusion: A >90% on "No" doesn't seem right. The criteria for this question are not insurmountable. We know that it has been done before (Waymo). Additionally, it's worth noting that Cruise doesn't have to reach Waymo's DPTM to launch a service. If it had a safety driver in every vehicle it wouldn't matter if the disengagements happen rarely or very rarely. Also, GM could pick a very easy city and launch its service in the suburbs. On top of that, it could choose to not operate during bad weather. Still, I am not reducing the chances of "No" to less than 80% for now as I am trying not to get swept up by optimism. After all, Cruise has a track record of missed deadlines and employees have raised concerns about the readiness of the technology (though it's important to define what we mean by readiness - again note the expansive criteria of the question). [4]  [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/821131
[2] https://arstechnica.com/cars/2018/10/waymo-has-driven-10-million-miles-on-public-roads-thats-a-big-deal/
[3] https://thelastdriverlicenseholder.com/2018/02/01/disengagement-report-2017-the-good-the-bad-the-ugly/
[4] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-gm-selfdriving-cruise-insight/gms-driverless-car-bet-faces-long-road-ahead-idUSKCN1MY0CK Tagging people who may be interested or have insightful arguments to offer. @Hammer-Time, @nigster, @Raahul_Kumar, @redsparrow, @michalbod, @cmeinel, @shivadiva, @acohen.

If "autonomous" really means able to drive unassisted on the public roads, then first a car would need to be proved to be safe, then surely a change in the law would be required. We are decades away from fully autonomous cars on the public roads. There are thousands of unusual situations that a human could cope with but an autopilot could not. Driving in a controlled environment is a solvable problem but driving on the public roads is way beyond our ability to write code for. There's just too many weird situations that a driverless car would have to cope with. Unique situations are rare but there's an infinite number of unique situations. Currently what do driverless cars do when they come across a situation they can't handle? They stop. So in all these situations they would just abdicate driving responsibility to the passenger, who might not have a license; • incident: paramedic says drive around
• incident: police officer says stop
• broken traffic lights
• road subsidence to go around
• flooded road. How deep?
• an accident blocks the road
• an accident blocks most of the road
• narrow road with cars badly parked
• etc etc etc, for infinity We drive using our subconscious brain for 99% of the time but the last 1% needs our full attention and human brainpower. If a self-driving car doesn't know what to do it must stop. Then what? Walk home? Wait for a software update?

There are many independent variables dictating this outcome. Legal, business strategy, technology, local government positioning, shareholder concerns, regulatory inertia, etc. Having the capability and launching a service are distinct things. GM will be shifting gears this year with closing plants and reducing capacity and investing more heavily in future technologies. Launching a money loosing business in 2019 seems like a non-starter. They have already lost first mover advantage, is there a difference between being second or third or fourth, especially when the anticipated markets are isolated and relatively small. Why rush a self-imposed DNA change - find a partner who already has it in their DNA and marry them. Leave the chest beating to startups.

Following the clarification (for which I asked), I see a larger chance that GM launches a service that meets the criteria for this question. If Waymo’s current service satisfies the question than it is much more coceivable that GM can get there this year. Cruise has been doing extensive testing and is catching up to Waymo in terms of miles per disengagement. [1] However, Cruise has recently been logging a only third of the miles driven reported by Waymo so it’s still a ways behind [2]. An interesting question is where Cruise stands in terms of miles driven and miles per disengagement compared to where Waymo was when it launched its service. [1] https://arstechnica.com/cars/2018/02/waymo-now-has-a-serious-driverless-car-rival-gms-cruise/
[2] https://www.fool.com/investing/2018/12/08/this-is-the-company-with-the-most-autonomous-miles.aspx

Here is some disconfirming evidence to the hypothesis for "No": GM continues to stand by their plan to roll out a service this year: "GM said it still plans to start a self-driving ride-hailing service this year in an unspecified city. "Dan Ammann, the new CEO of GM’s Cruise Automation autonomous vehicle unit, said GM still plans to deploy fully autonomous vehicles without human backup drivers for the service. But he also said the system may start with vehicles that have steering wheels and other controls." [1] If we assume that the "No" hypothesis is correct, then we should see at some point GM quietly dropping this commitment from their plans. Perhaps they do this as they realize that a well-meaning goal is actually less feasible than they thought. This is the thinking behind the "No" rationale. However, that is not what we are seeing.  This suggests that the posterior probability of a "No" should be lowered as we see GM stand by their plan. On the other hand, as I've noted before, the key part of the question might be "open to the public". GM could launch something but have a driver application process like Waymo's. [1] http://www.tribtown.com/2019/01/11/us-general-motors-forecast/

The current vehicles are not designed with steering intervention and this is why a service without steering wheels is more likely to appear initially.  Regulators may require human steering override to be available and thus a change to include steering cannot be ruled out. The time available to achieve this is very limited but the technology is available and has been invested in therefore some level of service is likely to be rolled out. The 5% exception is in the event of a newsworthy catastrophe involving the technology which would result in adverse publicity if the roll-out is pursued in this time-frame.

If Waymo hasn’t gotten there yet, GM will need more time as it’s technology is not as advanced. [1] https://waymo.com/apply/
[2] https://thepointsguy.com/news/waymo-will-launch-worlds-first-autonomous-ride-hailing-service/
[3] https://www.cnbc.com/2018/10/10/waymo-hits-10-millionth-mile-prepares-for-public-ride-hailing.html

Revising as I forgot that Waymo has already launched a service. This suggests that the technological bar is not that high and it’s more conceivable that GM will reach it. Regulatory barriers will affect vehicles without steering wheel at the federal level. But states might be happy to let GM start a service in their state as they race with each other to become development hubs for AVs.

Technological and regulatory barriers make this very unlikely. Even Waymo’s technology is very glitchy based on how the cars have been behaving [1]. GM has been running second behind Waymo in terms of miles traveled, so they are accumulating experience and I would guess they will launch a service at some point in the future. But I am guessing the technology won’t be ready to guarantee a margin of error small enough to expose it to human customers. Any company trying to do this will want to launch only when it’s confident that the tech is ready to prevent a backlash that could slow the whole thing down significantly.   I am not putting much weight on the fact that GM announced it. An announcement like that serves the purpose of telling the world that GM is aggressively working toward it, to signal to investors that GM wants to be part of the autonomous future and to scare off competitors. Its purpose is as a signal, less so as an announcement of genuine intentions. [1] https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=spw176TZ7-8
Assuming liability for accidents prohibits it
unlikely, but if they do. I believe they will start with a steering wheel, otherwise, an additional technology for remote driving is required.
road testing already underway for autonomous cars so more likely than not; given prior accidents people will feel more secure with access to a steering wheel.

Despite saying they will launch this in 2019, the only thing in evidence is that they've recruited a lot of money (from Honda, SoftBank) to throw at it. Many people cite Waymo's long road to launch as evidence this is impossible, but we know the pioneer has a disproportionate share of the burden for new tech. Plus, American car companies are desperate for a win, and I could see GM throwing a lot of resources into a Pyrrhic victory of second-to-market. This is one I'll have to update a lot over the next year as new developments occur. The no-steering-wheels thing is a fun red herring, but seems only slightly more likely than a car without brakes. I doubt we're close to allowing cars in which humans could not physically steer the car if they had to. It's just too counter-intuitive for legislators that still think people at Google are hand-selecting your search results to make them more anti-Republican.
Given the current debt levels, inventory on-hand, R&D expenditures will likely be slashed.
Feels unlikely given just how difficult it is to launch a service. I feel like many companies have announced this only to have the project fizzle out. Seems likely GM will end up the same position.

Would appear to be a tough road to get this up and running in the U.S. (- beyond perhaps a fixed-route option -) in 2019.
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-gm-selfdriving-cruise-insight/gms-driverless-car-bet-faces-long-road-ahead-idUSKCN1MY0CK ..Though GM says they're trying.. http://gmauthority.com/blog/2018/09/for-a-self-driving-car-ride-share-service-gm-is-keeping-its-options-open/
No chance this launches to the public within 1 year. Testing in some markets sure.
A year is pretty short and Waymo’s experience suggests it will take awhile.

People still don't like elevators without buttons inside. It's going to take much longer for them to accept cars without steering wheels. So, zero on those options. If Waymo isn't ready now, what makes anyone think GM will be ready in less than a year?  Remote chance, e.g., Waymo and GM partner for some reason.

Eliminating the fixed route makes this less likely in my opinion. While I'm sure GM is looking at launching in a city somewhere, the complexities of operating in a large city without a fixed route would seem to make this a challenge. Plus, the regulatory challenges will continue, and their will likely be little legislative changes to ease this process.
